channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kyiv Rocked by Explosions From ‘Kamikaze’ Drones
item.description: At least four people were killed in the attacks on the Ukrainian capital. Three others died in a Russian strike in the northeastern Sumy region, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taking shelter in a subway station after a series of early morning explosions on Monday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt Drops Most of U.K. Tax-Cut Plan
item.description: Jeremy Hunt also put a time limit on energy subsidies, seeking to reassure markets and reduce pressure on Prime Minister Liz Truss.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The statement by Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Jeremy Hunt, laid bare a government forced into a humiliating 180-degree turn in its economic policy.

item.title: Iran’s Loyal Security Forces Protect Ruling System That Protesters Want to Topple
item.description: The Revolutionary Guards — the country’s most powerful military force — have become so deeply woven into Iran’s economy and power structure that they have everything to lose if the system falls.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The Revolutionary Guards, a force with hundreds of thousands of members, is separate from the national army and is charged specifically with defending the ruling system.

item.title: In Xi’s China, the Business of Business Is State-Controlled
item.description: The Chinese leader has increasingly demanded that businesses conform to the aims of the Communist Party, an agenda he doubled down on this week at an important political gathering.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Chang Che and Claire Fu
item.media:description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping during his speech at the Communist Party congress in Beijing, on Sunday.

item.title: ‘Done on the Sly’: France’s Flawed Return of Skulls to Algeria
item.description: The restitution of the remains, said to belong to 19th-century freedom fighters, was hailed as a symbol of reconciliation, but papers obtained by The Times reveal a gesture muddled by politics.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Algerian flag draped over coffins containing the 19th-century remains of people who were said to have been freedom fighters. The bones were returned to Algeria by France in 2020.

item.title: BTS to Enlist in South Korea’s Military
item.description: Ending months of debate, the band’s label said that the seven members would serve their military conscriptions. They plan to reunite in a couple of years.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Bright Music, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: BTS performing in Busan, South Korea, on Saturday, the band’s first concert in months.

item.title: Protester Is Dragged Into a Chinese Consulate in England and Beaten
item.description: The scuffle came as tensions have escalated between Beijing and London, which has offered special visas to Hong Kongers seeking to leave.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Matthew Leung/The Chaser News, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A British police officer intervenes in a scuffle between a protester, center, and consulate staff during a demonstration at the Chinese Consulate in Manchester, England, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia’s Draft Sends Barely Trained Men to War in Ukraine
item.description: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts at army games in the Moscow region in August. Russia struggled with training even before September’s draft, experts said.

item.title: China’s Leader Xi Hails His Rule as He Prepares to Expand Power
item.description: Xi Jinping is expected to secure a third term as leader during a pivotal meeting of the Communist Party, extending his authoritarian rule over the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher, Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China on Sunday at the opening ceremony of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Macron the Disrupter Seeks Direction
item.description: He wants to lead a united Europe to independence. But the world has changed on him.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at the United Nations General Assembly last month.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Surrogate Mothers Have Survived the War
item.description: When Russia invaded, Ukraine’s once-booming surrogacy industry seemed at risk of collapsing. But surrogate mothers and agencies have managed to continue deliveries, and clients are arriving again to pick up their children.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Elections Approaching, Erdogan Raises the Heat Again With Greece
item.description: Turkey’s president suggested that troops “may suddenly arrive one night” in Greece. With inflation rampant and the lira sinking, a manufactured crisis might be just the thing he needs.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, during celebrations in Ankara in August to mark the 100th anniversary of Turkey’s victory against the Greeks in 1922.

item.title: When Cemeteries Are Flooded, Where Do You Bury the Dead?
item.description: Record-shattering flooding has submerged cemeteries across much of Pakistan. Now, with deaths from flood-related diseases mounting, families are struggling with where to bury loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: A flooded graveyard in Dadu, Pakistan, last month.

item.title: Tens of Thousands March in Paris to Protest Rising Living Costs
item.description: The demonstration occurred on the heels of strikes at oil refineries, adding to a tense political atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: Mayor Says Moscow Has Reached Its Draft Quota
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced what he called a partial mobilization of troops on Sep. 21. Defense officials had said Russia would aim to draft about 300,000 civilians.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian conscripted men saying goodbye to relatives at a recruiting office in Moscow earlier this month.

item.title: Generators Switch Back On at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant After Russian Strike
item.description: A Russian strike again disconnected the embattled plant from the national power grid, forcing it to move to backup power, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A blast on Monday morning disconnected the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant from external power sources.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Comeback
item.description: Republican leaders have embraced the former political pariah, demonstrating Trumpism’s hold over the party.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor-Greene.

item.title: What We Know About the Iranian-Made Drones Russia Is Using in Ukraine
item.description: Russia has used the drones to strike on the battlefield and in Ukrainian cities. Their use may be a sign that Moscow is running low on precision-guided weapons.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A residential building hit by Monday’s strikes in Kyiv.

item.title: Is This the World’s Most Picturesque High Dive?
item.description: Catch a glimpse of a storied tradition in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where, for hundreds of years, divers have leaped from a bridge in the southern city of Mostar.
item.dc:creator: Alessio Mamo and Marta Bellingreri

item.title: At least two drones appeared to target a city heating station in central Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The aftermath of a drone strike in central Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: A week after a round of strikes, Kyiv’s people take cover again.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a building in Kyiv on Monday, after explosions rocked the Ukrainian capital.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Troubles with Russia’s draft.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts at army games in the Moscow region in August. Russia struggled with training even before September’s draft, experts said.

item.title: Here’s what we know about the attacks on Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Megan Specia and Austin Ramzy

item.title: Strikes Hit Staging Ground for Troops in Russia’s Border Region
item.description: Explosions rocked Belgorod and the city of Donetsk on Sunday, signaling that the mayhem unleashed by Russia’s invasion is spreading far beyond the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A government building in the Russian-controlled city of Donetsk that was heavily damaged in an attack on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: China’s Leader Warns of ‘Stormy Seas’
item.description: Plus explosions in the Russian city of Belgorod and a fire at a notorious prison in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Debut
item.description: She has spoken more extensively than other newcomers to the Supreme Court have.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson

item.title: On tech, Xi points to self-reliance and state-led initiatives.
item.description: Mr. Xi signaled that little would change on tech policy, as he emphasized internet controls, state-led innovation projects and a battle for key core technology.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:description: Looking at a computer chip through a microscope at the China Beijing International High-tech Expo in 2018. China has struggled to free itself from reliance on foreign countries for microchips.

item.title: China Doubles Down on ‘Covid Zero’ Despite Economic Toll
item.description: Xi Jinping doubled down on the idea that the measures have saved lives and vowed to continue the stringent set of policies.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A temporary testing booth in a commercial neighborhood of Beijing, in September.

item.title: On Taiwan, Xi Jinping warns against international ‘interference.’
item.description: The Chinese leader struck a firm note on unification with Taiwan, saying that Beijing reserved the right to use force.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Russian nuclear fears loom in the geopolitical background for China.
item.description: On Sunday, Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, skipped the opportunity to note the dangers of nuclear war and the anniversary of the missile crisis of 60 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:description: A P2V Neptune U.S. patrol plane flying over a Soviet freighter during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962.

item.title: Putin Moves to Cement Annexations in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow is pressuring nuclear engineers to sign contracts with a Russian agency while pushing Ukrainians fleeing Kherson to go to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man walking in front of his home, which was struck overnight by a Russian missile in a town 30 miles south of Zaporizhzhia on Saturday.

item.title: Evin, Iran’s Notorious Prison, Erupts in Fire
item.description: Evin Prison, in Tehran, houses hundreds of dissidents and political prisoners. Witnesses described hearing gunshots and explosions as a blaze made its way through the facility on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: An orchestra conductor has been killed after refusing to cooperate with Russian occupiers, Ukrainian officials say.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Elon Musk Says His Company Will Continue to Fund Internet Service in Ukraine
item.description: The service has been crucial for communications in Ukraine’s army as it advances into territory occupied by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: Elon Musk announced on Twitter on Saturday that his company would continue to provide internet service to Ukraine.

item.title: Britain’s New Finance Chief Repudiates Prime Minister’s Signature Economic Plan
item.description: With Liz Truss’s authority ebbing, questions abound about how long she can cling to her post.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: In addition to her other problems, Britain’s beleaguered prime minister, Liz Truss, has never been known as a good communicator.

item.title: Rising Waters Again Force Evacuations and Spread Misery in Australia
item.description: In the southern state of Victoria, worst hit by the recent floods, officials warn that the danger will remain for weeks, with the ground already saturated.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: In Seymour, in the Australian state of Victoria, on Saturday. The states of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania have all experienced flash flooding over the past week.

item.title: Dressing Up
item.description: As the seasons change and more people return to in-person work, figuring out what to wear can be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Doubts Over Indigenous Identity in Academia Spark ‘Pretendian’ Claims
item.description: Some Canadian universities now require additional proof to back up Indigenous heritage, replacing self-declaration policies.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indigenous chiefs in traditional regalia during a powwow in July, where Pope Francis apologized for the Catholic Church’s role in abuse in the residential school system.

item.title: Three Women of Bucha: Their Deaths and Lives
item.description: New reporting illuminates the fortitude of three women — a former public servant, an animal lover, a grandmother — who were victims of Russian brutality.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Beijing Turns Into a Fortress Ahead of the Communist Party Congress
item.description: The authorities in China have arrested a million criminal suspects, curbed travel to Beijing to keep Covid out, and deployed an army of neighborhood monitors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Great Hall of the People (Beijing, China)
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of Xi Jinping on display at the military museum with the slogan: “Inspiring the Three Armed Forces to Forge Ahead.”

item.title: Peter Thiel, Major U.S. Political Donor, Is Said to Pursue Maltese Citizenship
item.description: Obtaining citizenship in Malta would provide another passport for Mr. Thiel, who is one of the largest individual donors for the U.S. midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Justin Scheck
item.media:description: Peter Thiel, the billionaire technology investor, during the Republican National Convention in 2016. Mr. Thiel was born in Germany and holds U.S. and New Zealand passports.

item.title: Coal Mine Explosion in Turkey Kills at Least 41
item.description: The accident was the country’s worst mine disaster in years, and the president said the authorities would seek accountability for “even the slightest negligence.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: People waiting on Saturday outside a coal mine after an explosion in Amasra, Turkey.

item.title: Belarus Wavers as Putin Presses It to Join Ukraine War
item.description: The country’s strongman, Aleksandr Lukashenko, finds himself in a bind. He survives with support from Russia, but entering the fight could be “political suicide.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops moving through a recently recaptured village in eastern Ukraine. Russia hopes that the threat of troops from Belarus will force Ukraine to divert its troops from front lines in the east and south.

item.title: Despite Its Barrage of Missiles, Russia Still Loses Ground in Ukraine
item.description: “They use their expensive rockets for nothing, just to frighten people,” a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said of Russian attacks on the country’s cities and infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops riding in the back of a truck near the village of Sydorov in eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Far from home, Ukrainians once again take to the streets to protest Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Under Fire, Liz Truss Retreats on Economic Strategy
item.description: Fighting for her political survival, Prime Minister Liz Truss fired her top ally and reversed course on tax-cutting plans, trying to shore up financial markets and her poll ratings.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain during a news conference on Friday, which lasted only eight minutes and in which she took few questions.

item.title: 20 Nations at High Risk From Global Warming Might Halt Debt Payments
item.description: The countries want their collective $685 billion in debts forgiven so the money can be invested in climate projects.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A barrier against erosion in Guraidhoo, the Maldives, in 2021.

item.title: How the fallout from Putin’s war doomed a farming village in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times

item.title: Elon Musk Foments More Geopolitical Controversy With Ukraine Internet Dispute
item.description: The world’s richest man, whose Starlink internet service is critical to the Ukrainian Army, said he could not “indefinitely” fund the system’s use in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Cassandra Vinograd and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Elon Musk, the founder of SpaceX, provided Ukraine with Starlink internet service at the start of the war with Russia. Now, it’s not clear if his company will continue to fund that service.

item.title: For Truss, a ‘Fairy Tale’ Unravels After Ousting of Kwasi Kwarteng
item.description: Having abandoned her signature economic plan, it remains unclear whether the British prime minister or her party can reclaim a mandate.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain during a news conference on Friday.

item.title: As the Bank of England’s Intervention Ends, Unease Returns to the Bond Markets
item.description: A two-and-a-half-week program of bond buying came to a close on Friday, leaving investors nervous about what will happen when markets reopen on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: The City of London, the capital’s financial hub, with the Bank of England building on the left.

item.title: Biden’s ‘Made in America’ Policies Anger Key Allies
item.description: The president’s plans to bolster America’s electric vehicle and battery production have opened a rift in relationships in Asia and Europe.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Ana Swanson and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Office of the United States Trade Representative
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 2022 Ford F-150 Lightning, the automaker’s electric pickup truck, in production in Dearborn, Mich. At the center of the trade fight is the more than $50 billion in tax credits to entice Americans to buy electric vehicles, but only those that are assembled in North America.

item.title: Report Criticizes C.I.A.’s Initial Handling of Havana Syndrome Cases
item.description: An inspector general report sent to Congress this week finds fault with the intelligence agency’s Office of Medical Services.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy in Havana, where the first reports of the mysterious ailments emerged. Some victims believe the incidents were caused by a foreign power.

item.title: Unrest Grows in West Bank in Deadliest Year Since 2015
item.description: Israeli security forces shot dead two Palestinians on Friday during a raid in the northern West Bank, after a week of intensifying unrest and shootings.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Members of a Palestinian militia walked through the West Bank town of Jenin during the funeral of a Palestinian man who was killed in an Israeli raid.

item.title: Dutch Princess ‘Can’t Really Go Outside’ After Threats
item.description: She started college in Amsterdam last month, but Princess Amalia is back living in a palace in The Hague because of concerns that she might be attacked or abducted.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Princess Amalia of the Netherlands, center, arriving for a speech by her father the king at the Royal Theater in The Hague, the Netherlands, in September.

item.title: How Security Forces Cracked Down in Southeastern Iran
item.description: A New York Times analysis of witness testimony and videos reveals a bloody scene that unfolded last month in Zahedan during Friday Prayer, with mats as stretchers and bodies piled in cars.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Nilo Tabrizy and Ishaan Jhaveri
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
